threads.author: _andax
threads.content: The main problem with the CH569W reverse engineering was that they didn’t include the register map for the USB3- functionality in the documentation. So it was a real detective work!

threads.author: _andax
threads.content: I wanted to make a high speed data logger…

threads.author: _andax
threads.content:
To a usb thumb drive. The Kingston DataTraveler I tested is rated for 900MB/s write speed.
What do you mean with check the numbers in the datasheet?
In the datasheet it has register descriptions for all peripherals except USB3 and the high speed lvds transceiver.

threads.author: _andax
threads.content: No microcontrollers in a reasonable package (non bga) supports nvme etc. I think it is a big problem that in principle no mcu support storing data faster than a few MB/s, except for the CH569W as far as I know.

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: There's an RS232 driver and a couple of RS422/RS485 drivers, OPO7 low-offset comparator, 74HC595, a few LDOs and buck converters, TVS and other protection diode devices, lots of diodes, transistors (incl ULN2003 octal array) and FETs, including high-current (>4A) PFET and NFETs, a few different op-amps, crystals, even a 16MByte SPI Flash chip. Obviously a selection of different R's (including 4-way arrays) and C's from 0402 up to 1206, and capacitors up to 50uF

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content:
The bare imported libraries are here:
https://github.com/cjheath/jlcbasic

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: All parts need descriptions. All "Value" properties are actually just manufacturer Part Numbers. I have fixed the incorrectly-imported 3D models, so they and the footprints seem to be all good

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: However I would like some help to do a mass-edit on all components in the symbol libraries, perhaps some form of scripting - but IDK if the normal Kicad scripting can do what I want

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content:
In short, for each resistor and capacitor, I need to:
- add (pin_numbers (hide yes))
- add (pin_names (hide yes))
- create (property "PartNumber"...) to be a copy of (property "Value"...) but (at 0 0 0)
- change (property "Reference" to be (at 0 2.54 0)
- change (property "Value" to be the semantic value of the part
- change (property "Value" to be (at 0 -2.54 0)
- change (property "Footprint" to be (at 0 0 0)
- change (property "Datasheet" to be (at 0 0 0)
- change (property "Datasheet" to be (at 0 0 0)
- add (hide yes) to (effects) of (property "LCSC Part")
- add Description text from the LCSC web page

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: There are hundreds of these, so I don't want to do everything manually

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: I'm not sure whether discussion on this topic should go to #kicad-libraries or to #kicad-scripting . Please feel free to redirect it to the appropriate place, and I will follow there

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: (Or for that matter to #importing)

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: I don't much like Python. If there was a Ruby or Lisp API for loading the Kicad s-expression files, I would jump at that.

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content:
so you send hardware plans and never had the hardware in your physical hands?

how did this work out? things just work frst try for you?

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content:
i always feel like i need at least 2 iterations before i am certain it doesn't have any errors anymore. ambiguous datasheets, flipped diodes, connection mistakes etc.

so you guys just send off the first draft like that? and it works 100% for the customer so he can go all in the design and orders 10k+ in a factory and there is no issues at all?

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content: so the customer just orders your first draft hardware for 100.000 $ or more and you never did a sample test? but it always worked out for you? they never came back with complains?

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content: my customers often want to order 10k+ in a factory. that is 10.000 units.

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content: with packaging, mass production etc. including assembly and case production etc. so the ready mass product. that is their goal, that is why they hire me

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content: but when i tell them this might take 2 years this often clashes with their idea of product development. which is 2 days for the plans that they can use to mass produce

threads.author: traumonaut
threads.content: so i am shooked that people never do hardware tests and just send a draft and be done. like wow i wish i could deliver this service to my customers.

threads.author: aqua.regia
threads.content: digikey shouldn't need a tax number unless it's a local regulation thing for your country and you usually get free shipping over a certain amount

threads.author: aqua.regia
threads.content:
generally you probably wanna learn electronics, not as much the program, (knowing what to draw vs knowing how to draw it) for the program itself I would recommend a look at the getting started guide here https://docs.kicad.org/ and at videos regarding proper schematic design before you start drawing something to make sure that what you're drawing is _readable_ to other people when you ask for assistance at some point, I can recommend these two videos and this post in combination
https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/28251/rules-and-guidelines-for-drawing-good-schematics
https://youtu.be/ywBPm7TMpfk
https://youtu.be/R_Ud-FxUw0g
with the Australian guy as always being a bit rambly so it's not as concice but still good

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: So using a mosfet here kind of opens up a little bit of a can of worms. They're ESD sensitive and they can have some unintuitive behaviour if you're new to electronics and are just expecting them to magically work. Using a BJT here, either a very ordinary 2n2222 if your load current is under 500mA or maybe a TIP41 if you need a bit more current, will simplify things a lot.

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: A circuit like this with BJTs would be sufficient for your application (you can add power input protection as you see fit)

threads.author: danny4574
threads.content: beginner question: what "cuts off" the gate for the red LED when the reed switch is closed?

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: The transistor on the left will conduct when the switch is closed, which will drop the voltage going to the transistor to the right down to zero

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: Or at least close enough to zero that it will stop conducting

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: Then there's the relay version which is even simpler

threads.author: danny4574
threads.content: got it! i was going to go the relay route, but i was thinking i might want to add a 555 to the mix (ambitious!) or a small microcontroller to blink the red LED when the door is open

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: On the subject of PCB fab, make sure you read up on the design rules for your chosen fab, and import them as best you can into KiCad. The defaults in KiCad are very conservative and are unlikely to match what your fab can manufacture.

threads.author: nicoya
threads.content: Anyway a 555 would be the easiest solution to understand from end to end. You'd still need a regulator to supply a lower voltage since the 555 has a max of 15-16v depending on the variant, but you wouldn't need to worry about learning the whole "how to flash a microcontroller" and "how to debug a microcontroller because nothing is working oh god help me please". Using discrete transistors to just switch the LEDs on and off would require vanishinly few components and still be relatively easy to understand, though making it blink would require a few more to make a simple astable multivibrator. The bonus for that solution is that there would be no need for a down-regulated supply: it could all run at 24v with the right component choices.

threads.author: seth_k
threads.content:
I've noticed that KiCad will touch the *.kicad_pro file when I open projects, and it'll show up as a changed file for git, even when there isn't a change to the content.  
Is there a way to prevent this?

threads.author: orange.scone
threads.content: git smudging: https://jnavila.github.io/plotkicadsch/

threads.author: orange.scone
threads.content:
Legacy, as far as I know. KiCad used to be 3-7+ (depending on how you count) mostly independent pieces of software with different formats for everything. There are long standing open feature requests to optionally make the symbol libraries act like footprint libraries and vice versa. You can give these issues a thumbs up on gitlab to show support if it would improve your workflow.

https://gitlab.com/kicad/code/kicad/-/issues/2490

 https://gitlab.com/kicad/code/kicad/-/issues/6917

threads.author: seth_k

threads.author: seth_k
threads.content: Unfortunately, it seems that it doesn't fix the issue
